item.description:
People don't dress like this for a reason - we do it for a cause!

 

THE ONE FUND

(read the details below)

 


We're expanding the garment requirements from spandex to costumes.. or anything goofy. 

We're asking for any kind of donation and we'll give it the Boston One Fund.  If we get a good response i want to have some T-Shirts made and should be given to those who get the most in donations.

The suggested donation per rider is $1 per mile of the bikeway.  $22 if you do the entire route. - but we'll take anything and there are no restrictions or limit. But prizes will be given to the largest donors.  May I suggest to ask for sponsors.

No you don't have to wear spandex but try to make it fun. Extra Credit to those who wear spandex your outfit will have to be pretty damn good to beat a spandex person for a prize.

Optional dress code ?? We need many people to come to make this a success. I hope you embrace the spirit of this and have some fun with your clothing. If you really are horrified of wearing spandex - we'll let you wear shorts over them. Or pastel leggings... or a long fuscia shirt. Just dig our your 80s wardrobe or halloween costume. I don't care.

10 miles more your speed? - We're starting at the Depot street parking lot and going to Woods Hole first. Then returning to Depot street before we complete the new leg of the path. So if you would like to stop at that point you can. Especially if you have kids who would have a tough time making the 22 miles. (or at least you can use them as your excuse)

The Shining Sea Bikeway (SSB) was named for a line in the song America The Beautiful, written by Falmouth native Katharine Lee Bates. It follows the original route of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad that used to run from Buzzards Bay, through North and West Falmouth, around Woods Hole and into Falmouth Station. In the early 1970's the Town of Falmouth purchased the right of way, tore up the tracks and officially opened the 3.3-mile Shining Sea Bikeway in 1975.

In 2009, a new 7.4-mile section was added, extending the trail to North Falmouth. This addition was built with a $3.2 million federal grant. Now the SSB runs 10.7 miles from County Road in North Falmouth all the way to the Steamship Authority parking lot in Woods Hole.
item.how_to_find_us: The Parking Lot is small but look for my White Toyota Sienna Mini-Man-Van

group.name: South Shore Hike, Bike & Social Club

item.name: Costume Ride for The Boston 1 Fund - Family Friendly
